content:
GM and Chrysler have been saved , yet wages have fallen for those on the line . Wages have barely budged since '08
Short of working a second job , most people would be hard-pressed to be earning more money now than they did when President Barack Obama took office .
Adjusted for inflation , the average hourly wage has gone up just 42 cents over the past four years to $ 23.41 , according to Labor Department figures . High unemployment explains some of this , but salaries have stayed disturbingly flat , economists say .
“ It ’ s unprecedented how modest the wage gains have been over this recovery , ” said Sherry Cooper , chief economist and executive vice president at the BMO Financial Group . “ It ’ s painful for consumers and detrimental for labor . ”
The issue hasn ’ t escaped the notice of Mitt Romney ’ s campaign , which started talking up the stat in response to Obama ’ s misstep last week that the “ private sector is doing fine . ”
“ Maybe he can ask families whose household income dropped $ 4,300 if they ’ re ‘ doing fine , ’ ” read a campaign email that went out Saturday .
The problem is even more pronounced in one of the sectors Obama takes credit for rescuing on the campaign trail — the auto industry . GM and Chrysler have been saved through federal intervention and car sales are climbing , yet wages have fallen for those on the line building vehicles and parts .
According to the latest government figures , autoworker made an average $ 21.65 an hour in April — about $ 1.52 less after adjusting for inflation — than they earned at the same point in 2008 . That difference adds up over time — more than $ 3,000 over the course of a year .
For Obama , this isn ’ t a problem that can be corrected in a few months . Many economists project it will take years before many Americans receive raises , simply because unemployment of 8.2 percent means the millions of job seekers out there allow companies to hire cheaply .
Wages will start rising again when unemployment returns to what economists call its “ natural ” rate , somewhere between 5 percent and 6 percent — the point at which the economy is again running at full capacity .
But at this stage in the recovery , low salaries reinforce a cycle that makes the economy fragile . Without additional income , consumers can not spend or invest in ways that cause gross domestic product to increase by more than about 2.2 percent this year .
“ That ’ s why we have modest forecasts , ” said George Mokrzan , director of economics at Ohio-based Huntington National Bank , “ instead of strong forecasts . ”

GM and Chrysler have been saved, yet wages have fallen for those on the line. Wages have barely budged since '08

Short of working a second job, most people would be hard-pressed to be earning more money now than they did when President Barack Obama took office.

Adjusted for inflation, the average hourly wage has gone up just 42 cents over the past four years to $23.41, according to Labor Department figures. High unemployment explains some of this, but salaries have stayed disturbingly flat, economists say.

Story Continued Below

“It’s unprecedented how modest the wage gains have been over this recovery,” said Sherry Cooper, chief economist and executive vice president at the BMO Financial Group. “It’s painful for consumers and detrimental for labor.”

The issue hasn’t escaped the notice of Mitt Romney’s campaign, which started talking up the stat in response to Obama’s misstep last week that the “private sector is doing fine.”

“Maybe he can ask families whose household income dropped $4,300 if they’re ‘doing fine,’” read a campaign email that went out Saturday.

The problem is even more pronounced in one of the sectors Obama takes credit for rescuing on the campaign trail — the auto industry. GM and Chrysler have been saved through federal intervention and car sales are climbing, yet wages have fallen for those on the line building vehicles and parts.

According to the latest government figures, autoworker made an average $21.65 an hour in April — about $1.52 less after adjusting for inflation — than they earned at the same point in 2008. That difference adds up over time — more than $3,000 over the course of a year.

For Obama, this isn’t a problem that can be corrected in a few months. Many economists project it will take years before many Americans receive raises, simply because unemployment of 8.2 percent means the millions of job seekers out there allow companies to hire cheaply.

Wages will start rising again when unemployment returns to what economists call its “natural” rate, somewhere between 5 percent and 6 percent — the point at which the economy is again running at full capacity.

But at this stage in the recovery, low salaries reinforce a cycle that makes the economy fragile. Without additional income, consumers cannot spend or invest in ways that cause gross domestic product to increase by more than about 2.2 percent this year.

“That’s why we have modest forecasts,” said George Mokrzan, director of economics at Ohio-based Huntington National Bank, “instead of strong forecasts.”
